Resident Matching Program (NRMP) is a private, not-for-profit corporation established in 1952 to optimize the rank ordered choices of applicants and progra m directors. The NRMP is not an application processing service; rather, it provides an impartial venue for matching applicants' and programs' preferences for each other consistently. In addition to the Main Residency Match for first and second year residency positions, the NRMP's Specialties Matching Service (SMS) conducts matches for advanced residency and fellowship positions. The NRMP conducted its first fellowship match in 1984 for Colon and Rectal Surgery, and in 2008 provided services for 37 sub- specialties within 21 separate matches. A full list of the specialties participating in the SMS for the 2009 appointment year can be found in Figure 1. The specialty matches occur throughout the year, and eac h requires its own registration process with the NRMP. Fellowship positions generally begin in July. Becaus e fellowship matches have appointments that start anywher e from 6 to 14 months after their match days, we have organized this report based on appointment year and no t match year. For more information about the NRMP's Specialties Matching Service, please visit: www.nrmp.org/fellow/. Data and reports for the NRMP's Main Residency Matc h can be found at: www.nrmp.org/data/. Instructions on ho w to request additional data also are provided. RESULTS AND DATA 2009 SPECIA LTIES MATCHING SERVICE 1 RESULTS AND DATA 2009 SPECIA LTIES MATCHING SERVICE 2 Introduction This report summarizes all fellowship matches conducted by the NRMP's Specialties Matching Service (SMS). Specifically, data are provided for matches conducted in 2008 (and early 2009) for appointments beginning in July 2009. In addition, trend data over the past five years show the numbers of programs and positions as well as match rates by specialty. Lastly, the numbers of positions offered and filled for each participating program is presented at the end of this report. The 2009 version of this report includes three new specialties (Endocrinology, Diabetes, and Metabolism; Neonatal-Perinatal Medicine; and Nephrology) and a new table. Table 5 provides data on the percentages of applicants who matched by program rank choice and specialty. In addition, the specialty-specific trend charts have been expanded to include additional measures and to allow better comparisons of measures with similar scale ranges. The 2009 appointment year was the largest in the history o f the SMS. The matches included: 2,507 programs within 37 specialties offerin g 5,763 fellowship positions Of those positions, 5,130 (89.0%) were filled Of the 2,507 participating programs, 2,055 (82.0%) filled all their positions 7,344 applicants participated in at least one of th e fellowship matches and 5,130 (69.9%) obtained a match Questions regarding the NRMP's Specialties Matchin g Service should be directed in writing to: Mona M. Using Allergy and Immunology as an example: The first two columns show that 128 U.S. allopathic me dical school graduates and 174 total applicants ranked at least one Allergy and Immunology program. The next two columns show that a total of 115 positions were offered in this specialty by 70 programs. The next two columns show that 89 of the 115 positions offered in Allergy and Immunology were filled by U.S. allopathic graduates and 108 were filled by all applicants. The percent filled (number filled/positions offered) can be found in the next two columns. Of the fellowship positions offered in Allergy and Immunology, 77.4 percent were filled by U.S. allopathic graduates and, overall, 93.9 percent were filled. The ranked positions columns show that collectively U.S allopathic graduates ranked those Allergy and Immunology programs 691 times and the total number of ranks for all applicants was 867. The last column indicates that 4 Allergy and Immunol ogy programs had at least 1 unfilled position after the Match. Of the 37 participating specialties, 23 filled more than 90 percent of the positions offered and 4 filled less than 75 percent of the positions offered. RESULTS AND DATA 2009 SPECIA LTIES MATCHING SERVICE 7 Table 3 The ratios of fellowship positions to active applicants from 2004 through 2009 are provided in Table 3 and shown graphically in Figure 3. Active applicants are defined as those who submitted certified rank order lists. The red line in Figure 3 indicates the point at which there are equal numbers of positions and applicants. The ratio of fellowship positions per active U.S. allopathic graduate remained fairly constant between 2004 and 2008 before increasing to 1.54 positions per applicant in 2009. Across all five years, there were more fellowship positions offered than there were U.S. allopathic graduate applicants. The ratio of fellowship positions to total active applicants decreased slightly between 2004 and 2008, from 0.87 positions per applicant in 2004 to 0.75 positions per applicant in 2008, but increased slightly to 0.78 in 2009. Taken together, these data suggest that the increase in the number of positions offered in the SMS matches between 2008 and 2009 was greater than the increase in the number of applicants when compared to the previous four years. The total number of registrants for the 2009 appointme nt year (8,086) increased 8.6 percent from the 2008 figure of 7,212, and the number of active applicants grew by 801 (a 12.2% increase). An active applicant is one who submits a certified rank order list of programs. Those increases can be attributed to both the addition of new specialties (Endocrinology and Nephrology) and the increase in the number of applicants for some of the specialties participating over the entire period. Applicants are grouped based on citizenship and medical school of graduation. For example, U.S. allopathic graduates are prior graduates of U.S. allopathic medical schools. U.S. international graduates are defined as U.S. citizens who are graduates of international medical schools, and non-U.S. international graduates are non-U.S. citizen graduates of international medical schools. The increase between 2005 and 2009 in active applicants has not been uniform across applicant types. For example, active applicants who are non-U.S. international graduates rose by 111.7 percent while graduates of U.S. allopathic medical schools increased by only 41.2 percent. Active applicant groups that increased faster than the overall rate of 54.0 percent are identified in Table 4 with green arrows. The trends in the numbers of active applicants and their match rates can be seen graphically in Figures 4. 2005 2006 2007 RESULTS AND DATA 2009 SPECIA LTIES MATCHING SERVICE 13 Table 5 Table 5 (new this year) displays fellowship match results by specialty and applicant choice. Applicant choice is determined by the placement of programs on applicants' rank order lists. For single specialty matches (top half of table), the data presentation and interpretation are straightforward. For multiple specialty matches (bottom half of table) they are slightly more complicated. Single Specialty Matches Using Allergy and Immunology as an example, there were at total of 174 applicants, of whom 108 matched. Of the 108 matched applicants, 39.1 percent matched to the program that was listed first on their rank order list, 13.8 percent matched to their second choice, 6.9 percent to their 3rd choi ce, and 2.3 percent to a choice further down on their list. Sixty-six applicants in the Allergy and Immunology Fellow ship Match did not match, representing 37.9 percent of the total number of applicants. Combined Specialties Matches In order to count applicants only once for the combined spec ialties matches, they are included in the counts for the specialty that they ranked first on their rank order lists (preferred specialty). Because these applicants can match to other specialties within the same match, "Matched in Another Specialty" data also are provided. For example, Cardiovascular Disease participates with ten other specialties in the Medical Specialties Matching Program (MSMP) match. Of the 1,159 applicants who ranked Cardiovascular Disease, 1,147 ranked it first on their list of programs. Overall, 702 applicants matched to cardiovascular disease, and 702 of the applicants who preferred the specialty matched. Of the 1,159 applicants who ranked Cardiovascular Disease, 37.4 percent matched to the program that was listed first on their rank order list, 10.1 percent matched to their second choice, 5.9 percent to their 3rd choice, 7.2 percent to a choice further down on their list, and 1.5 percent matched to another within the MSMP Match. Four hundred and forty applicants who ranked Cardiovascular Disease programs failed to match in either specialty, representing 38.0 percent of the total number of applicants. ————— *Specialties are grouped by Residency Review Committees (RRCs). DATA 2009 SPECIA LTIES MATCHING SERVICE 65 RESULTS AND DATA 2009 SPECIA LTIES MATCHING SERVICE 66 Specialties Matching Service: Program Results for 2009 Appointments This section of the report lists every hospital that participated in the SMS, along with the number of positions offered an d filled for each of the institution's programs. Hospitals are arranged alphabetically within state. The list ing includes the hospital name (abbreviated in some instances); the program code, which identifies each program; the quota (the number of positions offered by the program); and th e number of applicants matched with that program. There are three reasons why a program that ranked an adequate number of applicants did not fill its quota: (1) the applicant s preferred other programs having vacancies; (2) the applicants did not rank the program; or (3) the applicants had withdraw n from the Match. There are also three reasons why applicants may not be matched with their most preferred program: (1) the program was filled with applicants it preferred; (2) the program did not rank the applicant; or (3) the program ha d withdrawn from the match. NRMP Program Code Structure The NRMP program code is a 9-character code based on the following criteria. The first four characters are the Institution Code. The fifth through the seventh characters represent specialty code obtained from the first three digits of the program's ACGME Code and designates the specialty (see below). The eighth character represents the program type: F - Fellowship program The ninth character represents the track: 0 - first program/track in the specialty and program type at the institution 1 - second program/track in the same specialty and program type at the same institution (i.e. 34th Street Clinic) 2 - third program/track in the same specialty and program type at the same institution (i.e. Rural Clinic).
